profileText: A Senator from Alabama; born in Greene County, Ga., June 30, 1802; orphaned, he was taken by his brother to Alabama in 1815; attended the public schools; studied law; admitted to the bar in 1821 and commenced practice in Montgomery, Ala.; solicitor of the Montgomery circuit 1822-1823; moved to his plantation in Autauga County in 1829 and engaged in planting; Governor of Alabama 1841-1845; appointed as a Democrat to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dixon H. Lewis and served from November 25, 1848, to November 30, 1849, when a successor was elected; again appointed and subsequently elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of William R. King and served from January 14, 1853, to March 3, 1855; chairman, Committee on Printing (Thirty-third Congress), Committee on Engrossed Bills (Thirty-third Congress); elected to the United States Senate as a Democrat to fill the vacancy in the term commencing March 4, 1855, caused by the failure of the legislature to elect and served from November 26, 1855, until February 4, 1861, when he withdrew; served as President pro tempore of the Senate during the Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Congresses; nominated for Vice President of the United States on the Democratic ticket with Stephen A. Douglas in 1860, but declined; president of the constitutional convention of Alabama in 1865; died on his plantation near Wetumpka, Ala., November 21, 1869; interment in Oakwood Cemetery, Montgomery, Ala.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Roberts, Shepherd H. "Benjamin Fitzpatrick and the Vice-Presidency.'' In Studies in Southern and Alabama History, edited by George Petrie, pp. 46-53. Alabama Polytechnic Institute Historical papers, 1st ser. Montgomery: Alabama Polytechnic Institute, 1904. Reprinted from Transactions of the Alabama Historical Society, 1899-1903, vol. 4, reprint no. 29.
Watson, Elbert L. "Benjamin Fitzpatrick.'' In Alabama United States Senators, 49-51. Huntsville, AL: Strode Publishers, 1982.

researchRecord.name: 1 letter in Charles James McDonald papers, 1834-1854.
In Fitzpatrick family papers, 1849-1927. 6 folders. Chiefly personal correspondence, some political correspondence, photographs, portraits and memorabilia.

recordLocation.name: Alabama Department of Archives and History

researchRecord.name: 1819-1892. 208 items. Chiefly legal papers, but some references to politics and family matters.

Items in Alabama gubernatorial papers, 1841-1845, including reward files, 1842-1845; pardons, paroles and clemency files, 1841-1845; militia files, 1841-1845 extraditions and requisitions files, 1842-1845; and administrative files, 1841-1845. Scattered items in William R. King family papers, 1714-1964; Edward H. Moren papers, 1841-1887; Branch Bank of the State of Alabama at Huntsville minute books, 1835-1848; Branch Bank of the State of Alabama at Montgomery minute books, 1832-1843; Branch Bank of the State of Alabama at Mobile minute books, 1833-1851; and Branch Bank of State of Alabama at Mobile records, 1833-1860.

recordLocation.name: Alabama Department of Archives and History
